Dear Jennifer Hope Stevens:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Visitation and family time; in person contact
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12421
Section • (1) An agency shall develop a plan of visitation and family
Description time for each child in foster care consistent with the child's
service plans, as required by R 400.12419 and R
400.12420 to ensure the safety and well-being of the child.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Foster care workers hosted an unsupervised sibling visit with a
parent and made a plan for one of the foster youths to ask for help
if needed. The foster youth requested help but was advised that
the visit was unsupervised. The most recent court order indicates
visits between siblings are to be supervised.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Complainant was interviewed by telephone on 5/8/2024. The only
additional information to the allegation provided was that Youth A
moved to a relative’s care and since that time, has become angry
and aggressive with Parent A and Youth B during visitation.
Complainant added she believed the visits with Youth A and
Youth B were to be supervised by Family Assessment Center due
to Youth A’s behaviors.
Foster Care Worker was interviewed via virtual conferencing on
5/7/2024. Foster Care Worker reported she was assigned the
case approximately a month ago and since that time, she has
been working on developing a relationship with Youth B in which
Youth B feels heard and respected as that is something Youth B
did not have with her previous worker. Foster Care Worker added
it is her understanding that all of Parent A’s visits are to be
supervised as, even though the court allowed for unsupervised
visits with the younger children, Foster Care Supervisor and the
previous worker decided Parent A was not ready for
unsupervised. Foster Care Worker stated she was not present for
the 4/26/2024 visit as it took place on a Friday and the Friday
visits were being supervised by Case Aide. Sometime after the
visit, Foster Care Worker was told by Youth B and Youth B’s
foster parent that Case Aide did not supervise the visit and
remained in a conference room located near the visit room. Youth
B expressed feeling brushed off and ignored when she went to
Case Aide with concerns related to her brother’s behavior during
the visit. Foster Care Worker stated Youth B was upset as Case
2

Aide told her she was not going to supervise and told Youth B to
go back to the visit room. Foster Care Worker stated she has not
received any information about this visit from Case Aide, Foster
Care Supervisor, or anyone else at the agency.
Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed via virtual conferencing
on 5/7/2024. She reported Parent A’s visits with her younger
children are not supervised, but her visits with Youth A and Youth
B are supervised due to Youth A’s behavior toward Parent A and
Youth B. Foster Care Supervisor stated Case Aide was told on
approximately 4/19/2024 Parent A’s visits with her younger
children were unsupervised and Case Aide was to be in the
conference room near the visit room during those visits. Foster
Care Supervisor could not remember how Case Aide was told
Parent A’s visits with Youth A and Youth B were to remain
supervised. Foster Care Supervisor stated there is typically a
meeting with the team to discuss any court orders and/or changes
to visitation, so there was likely a meeting during which Case Aide
was told about the change to the supervision requirement. Foster
Care Supervisor stated she thinks Case Aide got confused about
which visits were to be supervised which is why she did not
supervise the visit on 4/26/2024. Foster Care Supervisor stated
she heard Youth B came out of the visit room and asked Case
Aide to come into the visit room to watch the visit, but Case Aide
told her “no” because the visit was supposed to be unsupervised.
Foster Care Supervisor stated Youth A’s behaviors are
“destructive” toward Youth B resulting in Case Aide frequently
needing to intervene and “do the parenting” during Parent A’s
visits. Case Aide is trying to not intervene as much to allow Parent
A to manage Youth A’s behavior on her own. At the end of the
interview, Foster Care Supervisor asked what the court order
regarding visitation stated. When concern was expressed with this
question as Foster Care Worker’s understanding of the
supervision expectations did not align with Foster Care
Supervisor’s, and Case Aide could not be expected to know the
supervision requirement if the worker and supervisor did not,
Foster Care Supervisor stated she knew what the order stated but
there have been a lot of court hearings and court orders for this
case, and she did not recall the date or specific details.
Case Aide was interviewed via virtual conferencing on 5/9/2024.
Case Aide stated she had a misunderstanding of the supervision
requirement for Parent A’s visits. She stated Parent A’s visits with
her younger children were unsupervised and Case Aide was to
remain in the conference room near the visit room throughout
those visits. Case Aide thought the visits with Youth A and Youth
3

B were also unsupervised, so she stayed in the conference room
throughout the 4/26/2024 visit. She reported the visit was
supposed to be for 1 hour followed by a family therapy session.
Youth B arrived for the visit on time and Youth A arrived
approximately 30 minutes late. After Youth A arrived, Youth B
came to the conference room from the visit room and told Case
Aide Youth A was being mean. Case Aide stated it is not
uncommon for Youth A to be mean during visits, so Case Aide
had previously established a plan for both children to be able to
separate themselves during visits by going into an open room by
themselves until they felt ready to return to the visit. On 4/26/2024,
after Youth B had come to talk to Case Aide, Case Aide went to
the visitation room with Youth B to talk with Parent A. Youth A had
already separated himself by going to an empty room, so Parent A
was alone in the room. Parent A stated Youth A was being
disrespectful and mean toward Parent A. Case Aide remained in
the room, talking with Parent A and Youth B for approximately 10-
15 minutes until the family therapist arrived. When the therapist
arrived, the therapist, Youth B and Parent A went into the room
where Youth A had gone. Case Aide stated she does not
supervise any therapy session. When asked who informed her of
the visitation supervision requirements that led to her confusion,
she replied her supervisor or Foster Care Worker typically inform
her if there is change to visitation, but she did not recall when or
by whom she would have been informed of the change with this
family.
DOCUMENT REVIEW
Court Orders:
• 1/12/2024 - Family Assessment Center shall facilitate visits
between Youth A, Youth B and Parent A, weekly. Additional
unsupervised parenting between Youth B and Parent A is
allowed as requested by Youth B.
• 2/16/2024 - Visits shall continue and may be unsupervised
and at another location at the discretion of the agency.
• 3/15/2024 – No change to parenting time orders.
• 4/12/2024 – Parent A may have unsupervised parenting
time. Supervised parenting time shall occur only when
Youth A and Youth B are together.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as, on 4/12/2024, Parent
A’s visits were ordered to be supervised when both Youth A &
Youth B were present; however, the agency held an unsupervised
visit between Youth A, Youth B, and Parent A on 4/26/2024.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
4

Technical assistance was offered that Foster Care Supervisor
review the court order and meet with Foster Care Worker, Case
Aide, and Case Aide’s supervisor to discuss the court orders and
visitation expectations for this family as during investigation
interviews there was a lack of understanding by Foster Care
Supervisor, the newly assigned Foster Care Worker, and Case
Aide as to the visitation expectations.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
